__data__.text:
Multi-class classiﬁcation via Transfer Learning 
 for classifying dog breeds from images 
 Shashank  Verma,  Xiaomeng  Ye 
 Georgia Institute of Technology, North Ave NW, Atlanta, GA 30332 
 Abstract 
 We build a transfer learning based multi-class classiﬁcation model for classifying images of 
 dogs into 120 breeds. We use multiple pre-trained vision models to generate image 
 embeddings followed by a feed forward neural net to train the image classiﬁcation problem. 
 Our best model performs with a score of 0.257 on the leaderboard. 
 1.  Introduction 
 The Dog Breed Identiﬁcation 2023 challenge involves classifying images derived from the 
 Stanford Dogs Dataset  into a set of 120 dog breeds.  This dataset contains images of 120 
 breeds of dogs from around the world. This dataset has been built using images and 
 annotations from ImageNet  for the task of ﬁne-grained image categorization. The dataset 
 comprises 20,580 images with approximately half being available for training and the rest 
 hidden for testset. We are required to output 120 probabilities for each image input which 
 would serve as the model’s prediction for the image belonging to each of those categories. 
 The data spread is not very skewed with the most frequent breed occurring 125 times and 
 the least frequent one 65 times in the training data. 
 2.  Image Pre-processing 
 First we performed some basic image preprocessing which includes resizing all images to 
 300x300 pixels, normalizing and standardizing the color channels and transforming the 
 result to tensor. Upon further inspection of what the data looks like, we realize that some

__data__.text:
images are ﬂipped, rotated and even cropped. This leads us to augment our training data 
 transformations with such transformations. In order to not lose the actual training data 
 with these transformations, we over-sampled the training set and applied these 
 transformations which allowed us to have original as well as transformed images in the 
 dataset. Note that only the basic transformations are applied to the validation set and the 
 test set. There are some pre-existing set of image transformations like  AutoImageProcessor 
 from HuggingFace but we used our own custom one. 
 3.  Model Architecture 
 Our model uses the embeddings generated from a couple of pre-trained vision models 
 namely ResNet50 [1] and InceptionV3 [2]. These embeddings are concatenated for each 
 image into an embedding space of 4096 dimensions (2048 + 2048). These embeddings are 
 then fed into a neural network consisting of Dropout, FeedForward (with ReLU activation), 
 Normalization, Dropout, Fully connected and ﬁnally softmax layer. The ResNet and 
 Inception weights are ﬁxed during training and only the layers in yellow are in train mode 
 (i.e. backpropagation updates the weights). 
 The following plot shows how the image embeddings are able to distinguish between the 
 images of diﬀerent breeds. These are plotted using PCA on the embedding vector of images 
 resulting in 2-dimensional embedding. 
 2

__data__.text:
4.  Experiments 
 We tried using the resnet-18 model ﬁrst to generate image embeddings. As an upgrade, 
 trying to export resnet-50 embeddings for images turned out to be running into memory 
 issues, so we changed the architecture from exporting image embeddings and later using 
 3

__data__.text:
those embeddings to do the classiﬁcation to feeding the embeddings directly onto the DNN 
 network to output the probabilities directly. 
 Later we tried using a couple other pre-trained models like ViTMAE, InceptionV3, 
 DenseNet 161, etc. and also combining some of these models via concatenation of their 
 embeddings. In our experiments, inception model seem ed to complement the resnet well 
 and addition of densenet on top of it didn’t give any further gains while signiﬁcantly slowing 
 down the runtime. The table below summarizes some of the experiment results: 
 Model name  Model description  Validation Accuracy 
 Resnet-18 w/ 
 logistic  Using just embeddings from resnet-18 and 
 feeding it into logistic regression  0.7355 
 Resnet-50  Using just embeddings from resnet-50 and 
 feeding to NN  0.82 
 Resnet-50 + 
 InceptionV3  Concatenating the embeddings from 
 resnet-50 and inceptionV3 and feeding to NN  0.91 
 Resnet-50 + 
 InceptionV3 + 
 DenseNet 161  Concatenating the embeddings from resnet-50, 
 inceptionV3 and Densenet161 and feeding to NN  0.902 
 References 
 [1]  Kaiming He, Xiangyu Zhang, Shaoqing Ren, Jian Sun: Deep Residual Learning for Image 
 Recognition 2015 
 [2]  Christian Szegedy, Vincent Vanhoucke, Sergey Ioﬀe, Jonathon Shlens, Zbigniew Wojna: Rethinking 
 the Inception Architecture for Computer Vision 2015
